warnings: If you experience sharp or worsening pain during any movement, stop immediately and rest.
If pain persists beyond 7 days or you notice decreased strength or range of motion, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling, or a sensation of instability in the arm, seek prompt medical evaluation.
exercises: Pendulum Swings: Lean forward with your non-painful arm supported on a table. Let the painful arm hang and gently swing it in small circles for 1–2 minutes.
Resisted External Rotation: Attach a light resistance band at waist height. With elbow bent 90° and tucked at your side, rotate your forearm outward. Do 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps.
Cross-Body Stretch: Bring the painful arm across your chest and use the opposite hand to pull it closer. Hold for 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Doorway Pec Stretch: Stand in a doorway with elbow and shoulder at 90°. Place your forearm on the frame and gently lean forward until you feel a stretch in the front shoulder/chest. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.

Scapular Retraction (Wall Angels): Stand with your back against a wall, arms in a “W” shape. Slide your arms upward into a “Y,” keeping wrists and elbows in contact with the wall. Perform 2–3 sets of 8–12 reps.

warnings: If you experience significant swelling, bruising, or inability to bear weight, seek medical attention.
If pain worsens or persists beyond 5–7 days, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling, or severe weakness in the leg, seek prompt evaluation.
exercises: Standing Quadriceps Stretch: Stand on one leg, pull your opposite heel toward your glutes, keeping knees close. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Hamstring Stretch: Lie on your back, loop a towel around your foot and straighten your leg overhead until you feel a stretch. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times.
Straight Leg Raises: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other straight. Lift the straight leg to hip height, hold 2 seconds, then lower slowly. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps.
Glute Bridge: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Lift hips until your body forms a straight line, squeeze glutes, hold 2–3 seconds, then lower. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–12 reps.
Foam Roller Quadriceps Massage: Lie face down, place a foam roller under your thigh, and roll gently from hip to knee for 1–2 minutes.

pain_points: no current discomfort during walking or bending
full range of motion without stiffness
warnings: If you notice any return of pain, swelling or bruising, stop activity and rest.
If discomfort persists beyond 2–3 days after resuming exercise, consult a healthcare professional.
If you develop numbness, tingling or weakness in the leg, seek prompt medical evaluation.
exercises: Standing Quadriceps Stretch: Stand on one leg, pull your opposite heel toward your glutes, keep knees close. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times per side.
Hamstring Stretch: Lie on your back, loop a towel around your foot, straighten your leg toward the ceiling until you feel a gentle stretch. Hold 20–30 seconds, repeat 3 times per side.
Straight Leg Raises: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other straight. Lift the straight leg to hip height, hold 2 seconds, then lower slowly. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps per side.
Foam Roller Quadriceps Massage: Lie face down, place a foam roller under your thigh, and roll gently from hip to knee for 1–2 minutes per side.
Glute Bridge: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Lift hips until your body forms a straight line, squeeze glutes, hold 2–3 seconds, then lower. Perform 2–3 sets of 10–12 reps.
